chapterMetadata.title: Pair of Linear Equations in Two Variables
chapterMetadata.subject: Mathematics
learningObjectives: Represent real-life situations as pairs of linear equations
Solve pairs of linear equations using graphical methods
Solve pairs of linear equations using algebraic methods (substitution and elimination)
Analyze the nature of solutions based on the relationship between coefficients

sections.title: Introduction
sections.summary: Introduction to the concept of pair of linear equations through real-life problems

keyConcepts.name: Linear Equation in Two Variables
keyConcepts.description: An equation of the form ax + by + c = 0, where a, b, and c are real numbers and a and b are not both zero
properties: The graph of a linear equation in two variables is a straight line

keyConcepts.name: Pair of Linear Equations
keyConcepts.description: Two linear equations in the same two variables
keyConcepts.notation: a₁x + b₁y + c₁ = 0 and a₂x + b₂y + c₂ = 0
properties: Can be represented graphically as two lines in a plane

visualElements.description: Illustration of a fair scene with Giant Wheel and Hoopla game
visualElements.interactivityHint: Interactive model allowing students to try different values for the variables in the problem

examples.problem: Akhila went to a fair and spent ₹20 on Giant Wheel rides (₹3 each) and Hoopla games (₹4 each). The number of times she played Hoopla is half the number of rides she had. Find how many rides and games she had.
examples.solution: Let x be the number of rides and y be the number of Hoopla games. Then y = (1/2)x and 3x + 4y = 20. Substituting the first equation into the second: 3x + 4(x/2) = 20, which gives x = 4 and y = 2.

sections.title: Graphical Method of Solution of a Pair of Linear Equations
sections.summary: Using graphs to visualize and solve pairs of linear equations in two variables

keyConcepts.name: Consistent Pair of Equations
keyConcepts.description: A pair of linear equations that has at least one solution
properties: Represented by either intersecting or coincident lines

keyConcepts.name: Inconsistent Pair of Equations
keyConcepts.description: A pair of linear equations that has no solution

keyConcepts.name: Dependent Pair of Equations
keyConcepts.description: A pair of linear equations that has infinitely many solutions

visualElements.description: Illustrations of different possible relationships between lines representing pairs of linear equations
visualElements.interactivityHint: Interactive graph where students can manipulate equations to see how changing coefficients affects the relationship between lines

theorems.statement: For a pair of linear equations a₁x + b₁y + c₁ = 0 and a₂x + b₂y + c₂ = 0: If a₁/a₂ ≠ b₁/b₂, then the lines intersect and the system has a unique solution
theorems.explanation: When the ratios of the coefficients of x and y are different, the slopes of the lines are different, causing them to intersect at exactly one point

theorems.statement: For a pair of linear equations a₁x + b₁y + c₁ = 0 and a₂x + b₂y + c₂ = 0: If a₁/a₂ = b₁/b₂ = c₁/c₂, then the lines coincide and the system has infinitely many solutions
theorems.explanation: When all ratios are equal, the equations represent the same line, resulting in infinitely many common solutions

theorems.statement: For a pair of linear equations a₁x + b₁y + c₁ = 0 and a₂x + b₂y + c₂ = 0: If a₁/a₂ = b₁/b₂ ≠ c₁/c₂, then the lines are parallel and the system has no solution
theorems.explanation: When the ratios of coefficients of variables are equal but not equal to the ratio of constants, the lines have the same slope but different y-intercepts, making them parallel

examples.problem: Check graphically whether the pair of equations x + 3y = 6 and 2x - 3y = 12 is consistent. If so, solve them graphically.
examples.solution: Plotting both lines on a graph shows they intersect at the point (6, 0), which is the solution to the system.

examples.problem: Graphically, find whether the equations 5x - 8y + 1 = 0 and 3x - (24/5)y + (3/5) = 0 have no solution, unique solution or infinitely many solutions.
examples.solution: Multiplying the second equation by 5/3 gives 5x - 8y + 1 = 0, which is identical to the first equation. Thus, the lines coincide and the system has infinitely many solutions.

examples.problem: Champa went to a sale to purchase some pants and skirts. The number of skirts is two less than twice the number of pants purchased. Also, the number of skirts is four less than four times the number of pants purchased. Find how many pants and skirts Champa bought.
examples.solution: Let x = number of pants and y = number of skirts. Then y = 2x - 2 and y = 4x - 4. Graphically, these lines intersect at (1, 0), meaning Champa bought 1 pair of pants and 0 skirts.

sections.title: Algebraic Methods of Solving a Pair of Linear Equations
sections.summary: Solving pairs of linear equations using algebraic methods without graphing

keyConcepts.name: Substitution Method
keyConcepts.description: A method where one variable is expressed in terms of the other using one equation, then substituted into the second equation
properties: Useful when one equation already has a variable isolated or easily isolatable

keyConcepts.name: Elimination Method
keyConcepts.description: A method where equations are added or subtracted to eliminate one variable
properties: Useful when coefficients of one variable are numerically equal or easily made equal

examples.problem: Solve the equations 7x - 15y = 2 and x + 2y = 3 using substitution method.
examples.solution: From the second equation, x = 3 - 2y. Substituting into the first equation: 7(3 - 2y) - 15y = 2, which gives 21 - 14y - 15y = 2, leading to y = 19/29 and x = 49/29.

examples.problem: The ratio of incomes of two persons is 9:7 and the ratio of their expenditures is 4:3. If each saves ₹2000 per month, find their monthly incomes.
examples.solution: Using elimination method with equations 9x - 4y = 2000 and 7x - 3y = 2000 yields x = 2000 and y = 4000, giving monthly incomes of ₹18,000 and ₹14,000.

examples.problem: The sum of a two-digit number and the number obtained by reversing the digits is 66. If the digits differ by 2, find the number.
examples.solution: Using the equations x + y = 6 and either x - y = 2 or y - x = 2 (from 10x + y + 10y + x = 66 and digit difference), we get either x = 4, y = 2 or x = 2, y = 4, giving numbers 42 and 24.

keyVocabulary.definition: An equation that can be written in the form ax + by + c = 0, where a, b, and c are real constants and a and b are not both zero
A system of equations that has at least one solution
A system of equations that has no solution
A system of equations where one equation is a multiple of the other, resulting in infinitely many solutions

commonMisconceptions.misconception: All pairs of linear equations always have a unique solution
commonMisconceptions.correction: Pairs of linear equations can have one solution, no solution, or infinitely many solutions depending on how the lines are positioned

commonMisconceptions.misconception: The substitution and elimination methods always yield different answers
commonMisconceptions.correction: Both substitution and elimination methods should give the same answer if the system has a unique solution; they are just different approaches to finding it

assessmentIdeas.question: Form the pair of linear equations for: Half the perimeter of a rectangular garden, whose length is 4m more than its width, is 36m. Find the dimensions.
assessmentIdeas.answer: Let x = width and y = length. Then y = x + 4 and 2(x + y) = 36 or x + y = 18. Solving gives x = 7m and y = 11m.

assessmentIdeas.question: Given linear equations 2x + 3y - 8 = 0, write another linear equation such that the pair has (i) intersecting lines (ii) parallel lines (iii) coincident lines.
assessmentIdeas.answer: (i) Any equation with different slope, e.g., x - y = 0 (ii) Equation with same slope but different y-intercept, e.g., 4x + 6y - 20 = 0 (iii) Equation that's a multiple of the first, e.g., 4x + 6y - 16 = 0
